choices.text: There are no response from the nociceptors receptors when stimulated by blunt forceps
Pinching with toothed forceps causes stimulation of mechanoreceptors but not nociceptors
Pricking with a needle does not stimulate nociceptors
Sharp pain sensation is carried by a C fibers

questions.text: Mechanical nociceptors and its response to a probe with blunt object, a pin prick stimulus and toothed forceps is recorded as an output of a force transducer coupled to the stimulator. What could be inferred from this?
questions.solution:
Choice A: Mechanical nociceptors respond to high-threshold mechanical stimuli, meaning they typically do not respond to light touch but are activated by intense pressure or damaging mechanical forces.

  • A blunt object, such as blunt forceps, may not apply sufficient force to activate nociceptors unless the pressure is extremely high (below threshold).

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice B: Pinching with toothed forceps creates high-intensity mechanical stress that can activate both mechanoreceptors (for touch and pressure) and nociceptors (for pain perception).

  • If the pinch is intense enough, high-threshold mechanical nociceptors will fire, leading to pain perception.

Choice C: A needle prick is a sharp mechanical stimulus that typically activates high-threshold mechanical nociceptors found in the skin and other tissues.

  • These nociceptors are specialized to detect potentially harmful stimuli and transmit pain signals to the central nervous system.

Choice D: Sharp pain sensation is primarily conducted by Aδ (A-delta) fibers, which are thinly myelinated and conduct signals rapidly. This results in the first pain (fast, sharp, localized pain).

  • C fibers, on the other hand, are unmyelinated, slow-conducting fibers that carry dull, burning, or aching pain (second pain).

Key Takeaway:

There are no responses from the nociceptors receptors when stimulated by blunt forceps is correct because blunt objects do not apply sufficient force to activate mechanical nociceptors.

References: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Mechanical-nociceptors-are-activated-by-strong-stimuli-and-mediate-sharp-pricking_fig5_265246764

questions.text:
Choose the correct option from the given statement of enteric nervous system:-
i. Vagus is the only efferent from gut
ii. Functions independent of brain and the spinal cord
iii. Myenteric plexus is in the lamina propria
iv. Exclusively under the influence of nerves
v. Parasympathetic connects enteric to CNS
questions.solution:
Statement i: False- While the vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) provides parasympathetic efferent signals to much of the gut (except for the distal colon, which is supplied by the pelvic splanchnic nerves), it is not the only efferent pathway.

  • The sympathetic nervous system also has efferent fibers reaching the gut via splanchnic nerves, which modulate motility, secretion, and blood flow.

Statement ii: True- The ENS is sometimes called the "second brain" because it can regulate gut functions without direct CNS input (e.g., peristalsis and secretion).

  • It can be modulated by autonomic nervous system (part of CNS)

Statement iii: False- The myenteric plexus (Auerbach's plexus) is located between the circular and longitudinal muscle layers of the GI tract, not in the lamina propria.

  • The submucosal plexus (Meissner's plexus), on the other hand, is found within the submucosa, closer to the lamina propria.

Statement iv: False- While the ENS is a neural network, gut function is also regulated by hormones (e.g., gastrin, cholecystokinin, motilin) and local factors (e.g., stretch receptors, pH changes).

Statement v: True - The parasympathetic nervous system (mainly via the vagus nerve) connects the CNS to the ENS, providing excitatory input to enhance motility and secretion. 

Choice A: i, ii, iii → Incorrect (i and iii are incorrect).

Choice B: i, iv → Incorrect (both are incorrect).

Choice C: i, iii → Incorrect (both are incorrect).

Choice D: ii → Correct

questions.text:
LMN lesions are associated with:-
i. Decrease in muscle tone
ii. Spastic paralysis
iii. Babinski positive
iv. Fasciculations
questions.solution:
From above table

Statement i: LMN lesions cause flaccid paralysis, characterized by hypotonia (decreased muscle tone) due to loss of excitatory input to muscles.

Statement ii: Spastic paralysis occurs in Upper Motor Neuron (UMN) lesions, not LMN lesions. UMN lesions result in increased muscle tone (hypertonia) and exaggerated reflexes due to loss of inhibitory control.

Statement iii: Babinski's sign (upgoing plantar reflex) is a hallmark of UMN lesions, not LMN lesions. In LMN lesions, the plantar reflex is absent due to weak or absent motor function.

Statement iv: Fasciculations (involuntary, visible muscle twitches) occur due to spontaneous discharge of degenerating motor units in LMN lesions.

Choice D. i, iv → Correct (both are features of LMN lesions). 

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice A. i, ii → Incorrect (ii is incorrect because spastic paralysis is seen in UMN lesions).

Choice B. i, ii, iii → Incorrect (ii and iii are incorrect because spasticity and Babinski's sign are seen in UMN lesions).

Choice C. i, ii, iii, iv → Incorrect (ii and iii are incorrect).

Key Takeaway:

The enteric nervous system can function independently of the CNS, and the parasympathetic nervous system connects the CNS to the ENS.

questions.text: What is not seen in decompression sickness?
questions.solution:
Choice C: Hemodilution refers to a decrease in blood viscosity due to increased plasma volume relative to red blood cells.

  • DCS does not cause significant intravascular fluid shifts leading to hemodilution.
  • Instead, intravascular bubbles cause endothelial damage and capillary leak syndrome, leading to hemoconcentration

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice A: In severe cases of Decompression sickness, cerebral arterial gas embolism (CAGE) or retinal artery occlusion can occur, leading to temporary or permanent visual disturbances or even complete vision loss.

  • Other vision-related symptoms, such as blurred vision or scotomas, may result from neurological involvement or gas embolism affecting the optic nerve or retinal circulation.

Choice B: Hearing disturbances can occur due to:

  • Middle ear barotrauma, which occurs due to pressure changes rather than nitrogen bubbles, can also contribute to transient hearing impairment.

Choice D: Gas emboli can promote platelet aggregation and fibrin deposition by reducing the blood flow, increasing the risk of thrombotic complications.

Key Takeaway:

Hemodilution is not seen in decompression sickness. Instead, DCS causes hemoconcentration due to endothelial damage and capillary leak syndrome. The condition leads to the formation of gas bubbles, which can result in visual disturbances, hearing loss, and coagulopathy, but not hemodilution.

questions.text: Which receptor contributes to static 2 point discrimination?
questions.solution:
Static two-point discrimination is the ability to distinguish two distinct points of contact on the skin when touched simultaneously. This ability depends on spatial resolution and receptor density, particularly in areas like the fingertips and lips.

Choice A: Merkel cells are specialized mechanoreceptors responsible for static touch, pressure sensing, and fine spatial resolution.

  • High receptor density in the fingertips allows precise discrimination between two closely spaced points.
  • Merkel cells provide high spatial resolution due to their slow-adapting (SA1) properties.

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice B: Meissner corpuscles detect light touch and dynamic (moving) stimuli but have poor spatial resolution compared to Merkel cells. They are fast adapting receptors.

  • Fast-adapting (FA1) properties make them better for detecting motion (e.g., texture perception) rather than static touch.

Choice C: Pacinian corpuscles detect deep pressure and high-frequency vibrations.

  • Insensitive to fine spatial resolution, making them poor at two-point discrimination.

Choice D : As the option A is true not B and C. This is not correct choice.

Key Takeaway:

Merkel cells are responsible for static two-point discrimination due to their high spatial resolution and slow-adapting properties. Other receptors like Meissner corpuscles and Pacinian corpuscles are more suited for detecting dynamic stimuli or deep pressure, not fine spatial touch.

questions.text: Identify the marked ones in sarcomere?
questions.solution:
Point A: The Z line (Z disc) is the dark line found at the center of the I band, marking the boundary of a sarcomere.

  • Anchors actin filaments from adjacent sarcomeres.

Point B: The I band is the light band seen in striated muscle, composed of only thin (actin) filaments.

  • Extends between adjacent sarcomeres, with Z lines running through its center.

Point C: The A band is the dark band seen in striated muscle, composed of thick (myosin) filaments.

  • It spans the entire length of the thick filaments.
  • Contains both actin (thin) and myosin (thick) filaments in regions where they overlap.

Point D: The H zone is the central region of the A band that contains only thick (myosin) filaments, without thin filaments.

Choice B: It is the correct choice.

Choice A, C and D are not correct sequences.

Reference: https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Ultrastructure-of-the-sarcomere-the-regularly-arranged-thin-and-thick-filaments-make-up_fig7_268000616

questions.text: Match the following hormones with their receptors:-
questions.solution:
Insulin → Tyrosine kinase (III)

  • Insulin binds to the insulin receptor, which is a tyrosine kinase receptor. Upon binding, it triggers autophosphorylation of tyrosine residues, leading to activation of downstream signaling pathways

Acetylcholine → Ligand-gated ion channel (IV)

  • Acetylcholine acts on nicotinic receptors, which are ligand-gated ion channels. When acetylcholine binds, the channel opens, allowing sodium influx, leading to depolarization and excitation of neurons or muscle cells.

Growth Hormone → JAK/STAT (I)

  • Growth hormone binds to the growth hormone receptor, which is associated with the JAK/STAT (Janus kinase/signal transducer and activator of transcription) pathway. This activation leads to gene transcription changes necessary for growth and metabolism.

Thyroxine (T4) → Nuclear receptor (II)

  • Thyroxine (T4) is a thyroid hormone that acts on nuclear receptors. After entering cells, T4 is converted to the active form triiodothyronine (T3), which binds to thyroid hormone receptors in the nucleus, regulating gene expression and metabolism.

Choice C is the correct answer:

  • Insulin → Tyrosine kinase
  • Acetylcholine → Ligand-gated ion channel
  • Growth Hormone → JAK/STAT
  • Thyroxine → Nuclear receptor

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice A (a-I, b-II, c-III, d-IV)

  • Incorrect: Insulin does NOT act via JAK/STAT (it uses tyrosine kinase).
  • Incorrect: Acetylcholine does NOT use nuclear receptors (it acts via ligand-gated channels or GPCRs).

Choice B (a-I, b-III, c-II, d-IV)

  • Incorrect: Insulin does NOT act via JAK/STAT (it uses tyrosine kinase).
  • Incorrect: Growth hormone does NOT use nuclear receptors (it acts via JAK/STAT).

Choice D (a-IV, b-II, c-III, d-I)

  • Incorrect: Insulin does NOT use ligand-gated ion channels.
  • Incorrect: Acetylcholine does NOT use nuclear receptors.
  • Incorrect: Growth hormone does NOT use tyrosine kinase (it uses JAK/STAT).
  • Incorrect: Thyroxine does NOT use JAK/STAT (it binds to nuclear receptors).

questions.text: Peripheral chemoreceptors are most sensitive to:-
questions.solution:
Choice B: Peripheral chemoreceptors are most sensitive to hypoxia (low arterial O2 levels, PaO2 < 60 mmHg). When oxygen levels drop, these receptors are activated and stimulate the respiratory center in the medulla to increase ventilation.

  • The carotid bodies are particularly important for sensing hypoxia, ensuring an adequate oxygen supply to tissues.

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice A: Hypercapnia (elevated CO2 levels in the blood) is primarily detected by central chemoreceptors in the medulla, rather than peripheral chemoreceptors.

  • While peripheral chemoreceptors do respond to hypercapnia, their response is weaker compared to their response to hypoxia.

Choice C: Peripheral chemoreceptors do respond to metabolic acidosis, particularly the carotid bodies, by increasing ventilation to expel CO2 and compensate for the pH drop.

  • However, their response to acidosis is weaker compared to their response to hypoxia.
  • Central chemoreceptors mainly respond to respiratory acidosis.

Choice D : Alkalosis (elevated blood pH) leads to decreased respiratory drive, but chemoreceptors are not highly sensitive to alkalosis.

  • A decrease in CO2 (respiratory alkalosis) suppresses respiratory drive, but this effect is mediated mainly by the central chemoreceptors.

Key Takeaway:

Peripheral chemoreceptors are most sensitive to hypoxia (low oxygen levels) and respond by stimulating the respiratory center to increase ventilation. While they also respond to hypercapnia and acidosis, their primary role is in detecting low oxygen levels.

questions.text: What causes a decrease in GFR?
questions.solution:
Choice A: GFR= Kf (filtration coefficient) * Effective filtration pressure

For each nephron effective filtration pressure (EFP)= (Pcap-Pbow)-(COPcap-COPbow)

  • The glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf) is a product of the permeability and surface area of the glomerular capillaries.
  • A decrease in Kf reduces the ability of the glomerulus to filter plasma, leading to a decrease in GFR.
  • In glomerular disease Kf is reduced.

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice B: Glomerular oncotic pressure (πG) is the pressure exerted by plasma proteins, which opposes filtration.

  • A decrease in oncotic pressure would lead to an increase in GFR, not a decrease.
  • It is seen in hypoproteinemia

Choice C: Glomerular hydrostatic pressure (PGC) is the main force driving filtration.

  • If PGC increases, it increases GFR, not decreases it.
  • Hypertension or afferent arteriole dilation increases glomerular hydrostatic pressure,

Choice D : Bowman’s capsule hydrostatic pressure (PBS) opposes filtration.

  • A decrease in PBS would increase GFR, not decrease it.
  • Urinary obstruction (e.g., kidney stones, BPH) increases PBS, decreasing GFR.

Key Takeaway:

A decrease in the glomerular filtration coefficient (Kf), which is affected by the permeability and surface area of the glomerular capillaries, leads to a reduction in GFR. Factors such as glomerular disease can reduce Kf, decreasing the kidney's ability to filter plasma.

choices.text: Is lesser than anatomical dead space

questions.text: What is true about physiological dead space?
questions.solution:
Choice D: Physiological dead space is the total volume of air in the respiratory system that does not participate in gas exchange. It includes both:

  • Anatomical dead space (VDanat) - Air in the conducting airways (trachea, bronchi, bronchioles) that does not reach the alveoli.
  • Alveolar dead space – Air in the alveoli that is ventilated but not perfused due to inadequate blood flow.
  • Physiological dead space mainly consists of alveoli that receive air but lack adequate blood flow, meaning no gas exchange occurs.

This happens in conditions like pulmonary embolism, where blood supply to some alveoli is blocked, increasing dead space.

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice A: Spirometry measures lung volumes, such as tidal volume (VT), vital capacity (VC), and forced expiratory volume (FEV1), but it cannot measure physiological dead space because spirometry does not assess ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) mismatches.

  • Physiological dead space is measured using the Bohr equation, which requires arterial CO2 (PaCO2) measurements, not spirometry.

Choice B: Physiological dead space is always equal to or greater than anatomical dead space.

  • In healthy individuals, physiological dead space ≈ anatomical dead space because alveolar dead space is minimal.
  • In conditions like pulmonary embolism or shock, physiological dead space increases beyond anatomical dead space.

Choice C : Inadequately ventilated alveoli (e.g., in obstructive lung diseases like COPD, asthma, or pulmonary edema) cause shunting, not dead space.

  • A shunt means blood is passing through the lungs without picking up oxygen, leading to hypoxemia resistant to 100% O2

Key Takeaway:

Physiological dead space represents alveoli that are ventilated but not adequately perfused, meaning no gas exchange occurs. Conditions like pulmonary embolism, where blood flow is blocked to certain alveoli, increase physiological dead space.

questions.text:
What contributes to the latent period of muscle twitch?
A) Neuromuscular transmission
B) Excitation contraction coupling
C) Reuptake of calcium back into sarcoplasmic reticulum
D) Transmission impulse from nerve
questions.solution:
A muscle twitch is the mechanical response of a muscle fiber to a single action potential. It consists of three phases:

  • Latent period – The short delay between the stimulus and the onset of contraction.
  • Contraction phase – The muscle generates tension.
  • Relaxation phase – The muscle returns to its resting state.
  • Latent period is defined as time required from point of stimulation to beginning of response.

            Statement a, b, and d:  It includes time required for the nerve transmission of impulse from CNS to muscle then to neuromuscular transmission at neuromuscular junction to excitation contraction coupling (Conversion of electrical to mechanical event).

  • Statement c: Reuptake of Calcium back into sarcoplasmic reticulum (SERCA pump) occurs at muscle relaxation that is after contraction of muscle. 

            Choice D: As statement a, b and d includes causes of latent period hence the correct choice. 

Incorrect choices explanation :

            Choice A: It does not include statement d, so it is wrong choice.

            Choice B: It include statement c which is not a cause of latent period, hence wrong choice.

            Choice C:  It does not include statement b, so it is wrong choice.           

Key Takeaway:

The latent period of a muscle twitch is caused by the time it takes for nerve impulse transmission, neuromuscular transmission, and excitation-contraction coupling, but not by calcium reuptake, which occurs after contraction.

questions.text:
Which of the systems do not require ATP?
a. Paracellular
b. Simple diffusion
c. Facilitated diffusion
d. Antiport (Na/K ATPase)
e. Symport
questions.solution:
Transport process that is against the gradient (electrical, mechanical, concentration) needs energy in the form of ATP.

a-Paracellular Transport – Does NOT require ATP

  • Paracellular transport refers to the movement of substances between cells, across tight junctions, rather than through the cell membrane.
  • This occurs passively, driven by concentration or pressure gradients, and does not require ATP.

b- Simple diffusion- Does not require ATP

  • Simple diffusion is the movement of molecules directly across the lipid bilayer down their concentration gradient.

c- Facilitated diffusion- Does not require ATP

  • Facilitated diffusion involves carrier proteins or channels to help transport molecules down their concentration gradient.
  • No ATP is required because movement occurs passively.

d- Antiport- Requires ATP (NA-K atpase)

  • Na+/K+ ATPase is a primary active transport system that requires ATP to pump 3 Na+ out and 2 K+ in, against their gradients.
  • It directly hydrolyzes ATP to function.

e- Symport- May or may not require ATP.

  • If it is carrier mediated towards the gradient does not require ATP.
  • If it is pump mediated against gradient requires ATP.

Choice C: a,b and c does not require ATP hence true.

Incorrect choices :

Choice A,B and D: Does not include c (facilitated diffusion) hence incorrect.

Key Takeaway:

Paracellular transport, simple diffusion, and facilitated diffusion do not require ATP because they occur passively, following concentration gradients.
